Award.AwardTitle: Novel Lessons From Ancient Plants: water transport in the earliest tracheophytes
Award.AbstractNarration: Seedless vascular plants such as ferns and horsetails are among the oldest lineages in the modern flora and with origins in the Devonian, it is remarkable that these plants remain competitive in a world dominated by conifers and angiosperms. Much is known about the physiology of woody plants, but what explains the continued success of the seedless vascular group? The goal of the proposed research is to examine the ferns and fern allies through the lens of physiology, specifically plant water relations. Efficient and resilient water transport is critical for plant success, but whether water transport played a role in the evolutionary physiology of seedless vascular flora remains unknown. The proposed research has several objectives with the overarching goals focusing on the relationships between species' drought resistance, vascular anatomy, habitat and life history traits, and how these features bear on the evolution of early vascular flora. Anatomical and physiological data will be incorporated into a realistic model of fern water transport, the results of which will be used to inform a large-scale sampling effort across the well-resolved evolutionary tree of ferns. This will improve present understanding of the manner in with which specific traits facilitated deep-time diversification of the ferns and fern allies. Lastly, this project will apply a recently developed model of vascular design to seedless vascular plants, and thus complete the understanding of the selection pressures driving the evolution of transport networks across all vascular flora. Broader impacts include high school and undergraduate participation in a conservation based, long-term study of fern performance in the redwood understory, teaching modules in local under-served high schools and the mentoring of undergraduate students in the PI's lab.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ferns are found in ecosystems around the world. While typically associated with the forest understory, ferns are also common in tropical tree canopies, aquatic habitats and deserts, with some species being no larger than a finger nail while others growing to great heights with fronds spanning metres in length (Figure 1). Given this exceptional diversity in both habitat and morphology, there is much to be learned about the physiology of these remarkable plants. Indeed, ferns have been present since at least the Devonian, and they’ve persisted despite dramatic episodes of climate change and the rise of seed plants. Their 400 million year success story is one good reason to take a closer look at their form and function.

With this in mind, the goal of our project was to evaluate the ecological physiology of the hyper diverse Pteridaceae family of ferns. Over the past several years, our team has characterized the morphological and physiological diversity of 26 key species from aquatic, brackish, tropical understory, canopy, alpine and desert habitats with the goal of discovering novel means by which ferns have adapted to the demands of their specific climatic regime (Figure 1). Our research addressed aspects of leaf biomechanics, water transport, carbon economics and leaf gas-exchange.

The structure and function of the Pteridaceae ferns revealed both similarities and key functional differences in comparison to angiosperm leaves. For example, fern leaf petioles possess a fibrous layer, the sterome, that surrounds the cortex and vascular tissues, and reinforces the leaf. Interestingly, thickness and density of the sterome depends on the size and life history of the species: tropical species with large fronds have relatively cheap steromes composed of weak fibres because the leaf derives strength from a combination of turgor and geometry, whereas the tiny desert ferns have such spindly petioles, that without the presence of a dense, fibrous reinforcement, their fronds would surely buckle from the loads imposed by wind or rain. This is but one example of targeted economy in fern form and function.

Variation in leaf gas-exchange and water transport tissues is equally compelling. As expected, ferns adapted to the tropical dark understory had low rates of photosynthesis, but those growing in full sun were consuming CO2 at rates on par with many angiosperms. Because leaf water loss is the necessary cost of photosynthesis (stomata must be open to allow CO2 to diffuse into the leaf), these plants had surprisingly high transpiration rates. To prevent wilting, the supply of water to the leaf must meet the demand, so it follows these ferns were moving water throughout the leaf via extraordinarily wide and long vascular cells. In fact, these cells rival the size of vessels in angiosperms.

Taken together, our research revealed a suite of unusual attributes that allow ferns to withstand cycles of dehydration and rehydration, extreme heat, and water deficit. Alternatively, other traits such structural and biochemical adaptations to high light are convergent with those of angiosperm leaves. The physiological and morphological diversity of ferns may inspire breeders and geneticists to look for new ways in which to incorporate stress resistance into crops and other economically important plants.
